Dept. of Energy,</subfield><subfield code="c">2007.</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="264" ind1=" " ind2="2"><subfield code="a">Oak Ridge, Tenn. :</subfield><subfield code="b">Distributed by the Office of Scientific and Technical Information, U.S. Dept. of Energy.</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="300" ind1=" " ind2=" "><subfield code="a">179 pages :</subfield><subfield code="b">digital, PDF file.</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="336" ind1=" " ind2=" "><subfield code="a">text</subfield><subfield code="b">txt</subfield><subfield code="2">rdacontent</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="337" ind1=" " ind2=" "><subfield code="a">computer</subfield><subfield code="b">c</subfield><subfield code="2">rdamedia</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="338" ind1=" " ind2=" "><subfield code="a">online resource</subfield><subfield code="b">cr</subfield><subfield code="2">rdacarrier</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="500" ind1=" " ind2=" "><subfield code="a">Published through SciTech Connect.</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="500" ind1=" " ind2=" "><subfield code="a">08/01/2007.</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="500" ind1=" " ind2=" "><subfield code="a">"fermilab-thesis-2007-31"</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="500" ind1=" " ind2=" "><subfield code="a">McGowan, Aaron Michael.</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="506" ind1=" " ind2="0"><subfield code="a">Free-to-read</subfield><subfield code="f">Unrestricted online access</subfield><subfield code="2">star</subfield></datafield><datafield tag="520" ind1="3" ind2=" "><subfield code="a">The MINOS (Main Injector Neutrino Oscillation Search) experiment has observed muon neutrino disappearance consistent with the oscillation hypothesis tested by Super-Kamiokande and K2K. The survival probability for ν{sub μ} is given approximately by 1 - sin²2θ₂₃sin²(1.27Δm²₃₂L/E), whereθ₂₃ and Δm²₃₂ are the mixing angle and difference in mass squared in eV²/c⁴ between the mass eigenstates ν₃ and ν₂, L is the distance traveled in km, and E is the neutrino energy in GeV. In the Near Detector at Fermilab, a measurement of the energy spectrum of the NuMI neutrino beam is made 1 km from the beam target. The neutrinos travel to the Far Detector in the Soudan Underground Laboratory, where another measurement of the energy spectrum is made 735 km from the target. MINOS measures </subfield><subfield code=" ">and sin²2θ₂₃ by comparing the ND and FD neutrino energy spectra. In this dissertation, a n alternate method is presented that utilizes rock muons, a class of events that occur when a ν{sub μ} interaction takes place in the rock surrounding the FD. Many muons that result from these interactions penetrate the rock and reach the detector. Muon events from ν{sub μ} interactions in the non-fiducial volume of the FD are also used in this analysis. The distribution of reconstructed muon momentum and direction relative to the beam is predicted by Monte Carlo simulation, normalized by the measured ν{sub μ} energy spectrum at the ND. In the first year of NuMI running (an exposure of 1.27x10²° protons on target) 117 selected events are observed below 3.0 GeV/c, where 150.2±16.1 events are expected. When a fit is performed to events below 10.0 GeV/c, the null (no disappearance) hypothesis is ruled out at significance level α = 4.2 x 10⁻³. The data are consistent with the oscillation hypothesis given parameter values </subfield><subfield code=" ">= 2.32 ±{sup 1.06}{sub 0.75} x 10⁻³ eV²/c⁴ (stat+sys) and sin²2θ₂₃ > 0.48 (68% CL) which is in agreement with the published MINOS result </subfield><subfield code=" ">= 2.74 ±{sup 0.44}{sub 0.26} x 10⁻³ eV²/c⁴ (stat+sys) and sin²2θ₂₃ > 0.87 (68% CL).</subfield></datafield><datafield Free-to-read Unrestricted online access star The MINOS (Main Injector Neutrino Oscillation Search) experiment has observed muon neutrino disappearance consistent with the oscillation hypothesis tested by Super-Kamiokande and K2K. The survival probability for ν{sub μ} is given approximately by 1 - sin²2θ₂₃sin²(1.27Δm²₃₂L/E), whereθ₂₃ and Δm²₃₂ are the mixing angle and difference in mass squared in eV²/c⁴ between the mass eigenstates ν₃ and ν₂, L is the distance traveled in km, and E is the neutrino energy in GeV. In the Near Detector at Fermilab, a measurement of the energy spectrum of the NuMI neutrino beam is made 1 km from the beam target. The neutrinos travel to the Far Detector in the Soudan Underground Laboratory, where another measurement of the energy spectrum is made 735 km from the target. MINOS measures  and sin²2θ₂₃ by comparing the ND and FD neutrino energy spectra. In this dissertation, a n alternate method is presented that utilizes rock muons, a class of events that occur when a ν{sub μ} interaction takes place in the rock surrounding the FD. Many muons that result from these interactions penetrate the rock and reach the detector. Muon events from ν{sub μ} interactions in the non-fiducial volume of the FD are also used in this analysis. The distribution of reconstructed muon momentum and direction relative to the beam is predicted by Monte Carlo simulation, normalized by the measured ν{sub μ} energy spectrum at the ND. In the first year of NuMI running (an exposure of 1.27x10²° protons on target) 117 selected events are observed below 3.0 GeV/c, where 150.2±16.1 events are expected. When a fit is performed to events below 10.0 GeV/c, the null (no disappearance) hypothesis is ruled out at significance level α = 4.2 x 10⁻³. The data are consistent with the oscillation hypothesis given parameter values  = 2.32 ±{sup 1.06}{sub 0.75} x 10⁻³ eV²/c⁴ (stat+sys) and sin²2θ₂₃ > 0.48 (68% CL) which is in agreement with the published MINOS result  = 2.74 ±{sup 0.44}{sub 0.26} x 10⁻³ eV²/c⁴ (stat+sys) and sin²2θ₂₃ > 0.87 (68% CL).
